importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Paris Climate Agreement was signed in 2015 and marked a turning point in global climate action, setting a target to limit warming to well below 2°C, which directly influences the projected number of superhot days.
The study estimates that by 2100, under current commitments, the world will see 57 additional superhot days annually, indicating a continued and growing climate risk even with post-2015 efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The long-term projection to 2100 shows that even with current climate commitments, dangerous heat events will persist, emphasizing the urgency of immediate action.

keyTakeAways: The world is expected to see an additional 57 superhot days per year by 2100 due to climate change, which is half the worst-case scenario of 114 days under pre-Paris warming trajectories.
Before the Paris Climate Agreement, the world faced a 4°C warming scenario, which would have added 114 superhot days annually; current commitments reduce this to 57 days.
Since 2015, the planet has already added 11 average superhot days, showing that climate impacts are already manifesting today.

The increase in superhot days is not evenly distributed—small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will experience the largest spikes, with Panama projected to gain 149 extra days.
These 10 high-impact nations collectively emit only 1% of global carbon pollution, highlighting a significant disparity between pollution responsibility and heat exposure.
Top emitters like the U.S., China, and India—responsible for 42% of global CO2—face only 23–30 additional superhot days, indicating a stark inequity in climate impacts.
Experts like Johan Rockstrom and Friederike Otto emphasize that climate change still poses a disastrous future for billions, with tens of thousands or millions affected annually.
The disproportionate burden of heat impacts on vulnerable nations may exacerbate global inequality and contribute to geopolitical instability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that climate change has already added 11 average superhot days since 2015 and will result in 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100 under current commitments to the Paris Climate Agreement. This is half the increase from a worst-case scenario of 114 days under pre-Paris warming. The study reveals a sharp inequity in climate impacts: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa—accounting for less than 1% of global carbon emissions—will face the largest spikes in dangerous heat, with Panama projected to gain 149 extra days. In contrast, the world’s top emitters, including the U.S., China, and India, which are responsible for 42% of global CO2, will experience only 23–30 extra superhot days. Experts warn that this disparity could deepen global inequalities and threaten geopolitical stability, emphasizing that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by rising heat events, even as climate action has not eliminated the risk of catastrophic warming.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
